abstract.para: This documentation presents the use of the feature diagram editor to create feature diagram that respect some constraints.

preface.title: Preface
preface.para: Feature models are a way to add variability on models. By variability, we mean to model common and variable parts of a given architecture. An example of use of variability is given by Software Product Line (SPL) which consists in derive different family of products according to their similarities and differences. Another use is to model different software architecture possible choices. A sample for the feature diagram editor details this aspect. This document present quickly how to install and use the feature diagram editor with a sample wink video. For more information about this editor please refer to the technical documentation.

chapter.title: Feature Diagram Editor Overview
chapter.para: Many notations exist for feature diagram. The notation used on this feature diagram editor to take into account different needs appears on the different notations. So, features can be linked each other with And, Xor, Or, Cardinality and Optional operators. (cf link). For technical reasons, the graphical notation for this feature diagram editor is simplified. This tool separate modeling of architecture and modeling of feature diagram that describes the variability of this architecture. However, this tool permits to add Domain Model Elements into the features in the Feature Diagram model. The next section will present the installation of the Feature Diagram Editor, a quickly presentation of use and a sample wink video.

chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para:
Before installing new Eclipse plugin, you need to install SWI-Prolog on your computer. To install the Feature Diagram Editor you need to have an Eclipse with Obeo Designer and the Praxis Constraints installed :
Install Acceleo update site
Install Obeo Designer Architect update site
Install the license for Obeo Designer (it is a commercial product)
Install Mofscript update site : http://download.eclipse.org/modeling/gmt/mofscript/update/
Install EMF Text SDK http://reuseware.org/update
Then install Praxis and choose only :
Consistency rules
Praxis Bridge Java
SWIPL
Praxis Feature

To install the Feature Diagram editor unzip the update site fr.inria.featureDiagramEditor.updatesite, open Eclipse and go to Help -> Install New Software. On the new wizard, click on Add name your new update site Feature Diagram Editor and search the unzipped update site.

chapter.title: Feature Diagram Editor : Quick presentation
chapter.para: This chapter present a very quick of use of Feature Diagram Editor. For more information please refer to the sample wink video.

section.title: Create a new Feature Diagram Model
section.para: Our editor needs the use of the Design perspective like in Obeo Designer to create or use a Domain Specific Language (DSL). So, go to Window-> Open Perspective -> Other -> Design. Two views appear on the left, Project Explorer and Model Contents.
To create a new feature model , start with creating a new general project in the Project Explorer view (File -> New -> Other -> General -> Project).

Then, create a new Session (File -> New -> Local Session) on Design perspective. Click on empty session.. Next, right click on the "folder " in the Model Contents view, Add semantic resource . You can choose a EMF feature diagram model ever created with the feature diagram EMF editor proposed with this graphical editor or create a new EMF model selecting Create resource and http://www.kermeta.org/featureDiagram as metamodel URI.

Do no forget to give the extension .featurediagram to the new EMF file created by this way. Otherwise, you could not use the Praxis contraints associated to this feature diagram editor on it. Then, go to the Model Contents view and click on the folder to find "New Feature Diagram Editor " with a green icon at the left. Doble click on it, a GMF-like graphical model editor appears. If you do not see the "New Feature Diagram Editor ", right click on the root of the EMF model contained in the session -> New -> New Feature Diagram Editor.

section.title: Create model elements with the palette
section.para: To add graphical element on the feature diagram simply click on the desired tool on drag and drop it in the feature diagram. The following figure presents the feature diagram editor.

Now, we present the elements that we can see on the palette :
Root feature : in case of features model as a tree (boolean graphStyleTree at true on FeatureDiagram element) , this feature is the top node parent of any other features.
Feature : a simple feature. Features are used to represent different alternatives.
Attribute : an attribute (with a name, a value and a type) can be added into Features adding information.
Model : this element is added on features and consits on a container for domain model element that we can add on features.
Opt : the feature children of this operator are optional. in term of choices of alternatives. The optional features ( like feature a of the example) are colored in orange, and they are linked to the operator with a white diamond.
Or : this operator means that at least on of its features must be chosen.
Xor : this operator means that only one feature must be chosen between its features.
And : all features contained on this operator must be chosen. They are linked to the operator with a black diamond.
Card : this operator permits to choose a given number of features children included between a lower bound (cardinality minimum) and a upper bound (cardinality maximum).
Require : this graphical constraint represents a feature that require another one.
Mutex : this graphical constraint link the features that are mutually exclusive each other. It means that these two features cannot be chosen together.
Operator to features : it is a link that rely operators to their features.
Elements : Domain elements of any EMF metamodel. They are EObject.
To the current version do not use the Element tools in the palette. The next section presents how to add domain model elements into features.
The next section presents how to add domain model element into features.

section.title: Add domain model elements into features
section.para: Note that this way to add model elements into features is temporary. If you want to add some model elements stored into a given model, drag and drop this model from the Project Explorer view to the Model Contents view.

Then select a Model container of a feature and go to the Properties View. (If Properties View are not displayed right click on the feature diagram (container of the features in blank on the editor)) -> Show Property View. Click on the button at the right of elements. A wizard appears. Then, select the model element you want to add.

section.title: Check Praxis Constraints
section.para: To start with, you need to open the Consistency view. To do that, go to Window -> Show View -> Other -> Consistency -> Consistency. Then go to the Project Explorer view and right click on the EMF model contained by the session (file .aird) , -> Praxis-> Activate Consistency Management. The > Consistency view dectects the inconsistencies a give the name of features where problems are detected.

chapter.title: Conclusion
chapter.para: This document made a quick tour of the Feature Diagram Editor functionalities. For more details please refer to the wink video . An example is also available on fr.inria.featureDiagramEditor.praxisConstraints.tests (which is the contraints test project). To retrieve this project go to File-> New -> Example -> Feature Diagram Editor Sample -> Feature Diagram Editor Test Constraints.
